hints: The command center of the central nervous system.
Protected by the skull.
The organ responsible for thought and memory.
A muscular organ that pumps blood.
Located in the chest, between the lungs.
It has four chambers.
The primary organs of the respiratory system.
Responsible for gas exchange.
You have two of them.
A large organ in the abdomen that produces bile.
Detoxifies chemicals and metabolizes drugs.
It can regenerate its own tissue.
Filter blood and produce urine.
Two bean-shaped organs in your back.
They are part of the urinary system.
A J-shaped organ in the digestive system.
Breaks down food with acid and enzymes.
Connects the esophagus to the small intestine.
The framework of bones that supports the body.
Protects internal organs.
It gives the body its shape.
Tissues that contract to produce movement.
Makes up a large portion of the body's mass.
There are three types: smooth, cardiac, and skeletal.
The larger of the two bones in the lower leg.
Commonly known as the shin bone.
It connects the knee to the ankle.
The longest and strongest bone in the body.
It is located in the thigh.
Commonly known as the thigh bone.
The long bone in the upper arm.
It connects the shoulder to the elbow.
Funny bone is a common term for its lower end.
One of the two long bones of the forearm.
It's on the thumb side of the arm.
It rotates around the other forearm bone.
The other long bone of the forearm.
It's on the pinky side of the arm.
Its upper end forms the elbow joint.
A bony structure that forms the head.
It protects the brain.
Composed of the cranium and the mandible.
Curved bones forming the rib cage.
They protect the heart and lungs.
Most people have 12 pairs.
The bones that make up the spinal column.
They protect the spinal cord.
There are typically 33 of them in a human.
The central support of the body.
Also known as the vertebral column.
Runs from the skull to the pelvis.
A muscular tube connecting the throat to the stomach.
Also known as the food pipe.
Part of the digestive system.
A tube connecting the larynx to the bronchi.
Also known as the windpipe.
Allows air to pass to and from the lungs.
A large muscle located at the base of the chest cavity.
Plays a crucial role in breathing.
Its contraction causes air to rush into the lungs.
Blood vessels that carry oxygen-rich blood away from the heart.
The aorta is the largest one.
They have thick, muscular walls.
Blood vessels that carry deoxygenated blood back to the heart.
They often have valves to prevent backflow.
They appear blue under the skin.
The smallest blood vessels in the body.
Connects arteries to veins.
Site of exchange of oxygen and nutrients.
One of the two upper chambers of the heart.
Receives blood returning to the heart.
You have a left and a right one.
One of the two lower chambers of the heart.
Pumps blood out of the heart.
You have a left and a right one.
The basic unit of the nervous system.
Also known as a nerve cell.
Transmits electrical and chemical signals.
The long, slender part of a nerve cell.
Carries nerve impulses away from the cell body.
Often insulated by a myelin sheath.
The junction between two nerve cells.
Chemicals called neurotransmitters cross this gap.
Where a nerve impulse is transmitted.
The light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye.
Contains rods and cones.
Converts light into nerve signals.
The transparent outer layer of the eye.
Helps to focus light.
It has no blood vessels.
The black opening in the center of the iris.
Controls the amount of light entering the eye.
It gets smaller in bright light.
The colored part of the eye.
Controls the size of the pupil.
It gives the eye its distinctive color.
A snail-shaped structure in the inner ear.
Contains hair cells that sense sound vibrations.
Converts sound waves into nerve signals.
Also known as the eardrum.
Separates the outer and middle ear.
Vibrates in response to sound waves.
The bones of the fingers and toes.
Each finger and toe has two or three of these.
There are 14 of them in each hand and foot.
The eight bones of the wrist.
They form the carpus.
They connect the forearm bones to the metacarpals.
The bones of the ankle and heel.
They are seven in number.
They connect the lower leg to the metatarsals.
A long bone that runs horizontally across the chest.
Also known as the collarbone.
Connects the sternum to the scapula.
A large, flat bone on the upper back.
Also known as the shoulder blade.
It connects the humerus to the clavicle.
A flat bone in the center of the chest.
Also known as the breastbone.
Most ribs attach to it.
A basin-shaped structure at the base of the spine.
Also known as the hip bone.
It supports the upper body.
A small, triangular bone in front of the knee joint.
Also known as the kneecap.
Protects the knee joint.
Glands located on top of the kidneys.
Produce hormones like adrenaline and cortisol.
Part of the endocrine system.
A butterfly-shaped gland in the neck.
Produces hormones that regulate metabolism.
Requires iodine to function properly.
A pea-sized gland at the base of the brain.
Often called the 'master gland'.
Controls other endocrine glands.
A gland located behind the stomach.
Produces insulin and glucagon.
Aids in both digestion and hormone production.
A tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder.
There is one for each kidney.
It is a muscular tube.
A hollow, muscular organ in the pelvic cavity.
Stores urine.
It can hold about 400-600 mL of urine.
A tube that carries urine from the bladder out of the body.
In males, it also carries semen.
It is part of the urinary system.
A waste product from the breakdown of protein.
It is the main component of urine.
Filtered out by the kidneys.
The largest artery in the body.
It originates from the left ventricle of the heart.
Carries oxygenated blood to the rest of the body.
The largest vein in the body.
It carries deoxygenated blood back to the heart.
There is a superior and an inferior one.
The two main air passages that branch from the trachea.
Lead into the lungs.
Plural form of bronchus.
Tiny air sacs in the lungs.
The site of gas exchange.
They look like a bunch of grapes.
The female reproductive glands.
Produce eggs and hormones like estrogen.
Located in the pelvic area.
A hollow, pear-shaped organ in the female pelvis.
Where a fetus develops during pregnancy.
Also known as the womb.
The male reproductive glands.
Produce sperm and the hormone testosterone.
They are located in the scrotum.
A gland in the male reproductive system.
Located below the bladder.
Produces a fluid that helps nourish sperm.
A polysaccharide that is the main storage form of glucose.
Stored primarily in the liver and muscles.
Serves as a secondary long-term energy source.
A protein in red blood cells.
Carries oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body.
Gives blood its red color.
Also known as platelets.
Small, colorless cell fragments in blood.
Their function is to stop bleeding by clotting.
Also known as white blood cells.
They are part of the immune system.
Fight against infections and foreign invaders.
Also known as red blood cells.
The most common type of blood cell.
Carries oxygen throughout the body.
The outermost layer of the skin.
Acts as a protective barrier.
Contains no blood vessels.
The layer of skin beneath the epidermis.
Contains hair follicles, sweat glands, and nerve endings.
Where collagen and elastin are found.
A dark pigment found in skin, hair, and eyes.
Provides natural protection from UV light.
Its amount determines skin color.
A thin casing of connective tissue.
Wraps around muscles, organs, and bones.
Helps to reduce friction.
A flexible connective tissue.
Found in joints, nose, and ears.
It has no blood supply of its own.
A fibrous connective tissue.
Connects muscle to bone.
The Achilles' one is the largest.
A fibrous connective tissue.
Connects bone to bone.
Helps to stabilize joints.
The site where two or more bones meet.
Another word for a joint.
Allows for movement.
The part of the skull that encloses the brain.
Composed of multiple bones joined together.
Protects the brain.
The largest and strongest bone of the face.
Also known as the lower jaw.
It's the only mobile bone of the skull.
A pair of bones that form the upper jaw.
They hold the upper teeth.
They also form the floor of the nasal cavity.
A paired facial bone.
Also known as the cheekbone.
Forms part of the orbit of the eye.
A bony structure enclosing the chest cavity.
Protects the heart and lungs.
Made up of the sternum and ribs.
The main, central part of a long bone.
Also known as the shaft.
Contains the medullary cavity.
The end part of a long bone.
Found at the ends of the diaphysis.
Larger in circumference than the shaft.
A soft, fatty tissue found inside bones.
Red one produces blood cells.
Yellow one stores fat.
A pair of ligaments in the knee joint.
They cross each other, forming an 'X'.
Stabilizes the knee.
A piece of cartilage in the knee.
Acts as a shock absorber.
There are two of them in each knee.
A part of the brainstem.
Located above the medulla oblongata.
Responsible for relaying signals and sleep regulation.
The lower half of the brainstem.
Controls vital involuntary functions.
Regulates breathing, heart rate, and blood pressure.
A region of the brain located behind the brainstem.
Known as the 'little brain'.
Plays a key role in motor control and balance.
The largest part of the brain.
Divided into two hemispheres.
Responsible for voluntary actions, thought, and language.
The outer layer of the cerebrum.
Also known as gray matter.
Where conscious thought and intelligence reside.
A large mass of gray matter in the forebrain.
Relays sensory signals to the cerebral cortex.
Often called the 'gateway to the cortex'.
A small region of the brain below the thalamus.
Links the nervous system to the endocrine system.
Controls body temperature, hunger, and thirst.
A part of the brain's limbic system.
Crucial for the formation of new memories.
Its name means 'sea horse'.
A almond-shaped structure in the brain.
Plays a role in processing emotions, particularly fear.
Part of the limbic system.
The muscular tissue of the heart.
Contracts to pump blood.
What makes up the walls of the ventricles and atria.
A sac that encloses the heart.
Protects and lubricates the heart.
It has a fibrous and a serous layer.
Wave-like muscle contractions.
Moves food through the digestive tract.
Occurs in the esophagus and intestines.
The first part of the small intestine.
Receives partially digested food from the stomach.
Where most chemical digestion occurs.
The middle section of the small intestine.
Follows the duodenum.
Where absorption of nutrients takes place.
The final section of the small intestine.
Absorbs vitamin B12 and bile acids.
Connects to the large intestine.
The beginning of the large intestine.
A pouch-like structure.
The appendix is attached to it.
The longest part of the large intestine.
Absorbs water and electrolytes.
Divided into ascending, transverse, and descending parts.
The final section of the large intestine.
Stores feces before elimination.
Located just before the anus.
A blood vessel that carries blood from the GI tract to the liver.
Delivers nutrients and toxins for processing.
Does not carry blood to the heart.
A small organ near the liver.
Stores and concentrates bile.
Can be removed without major issues.
A fluid produced by the liver.
Aids in the digestion of fats.
Stored in the gallbladder.
A flap of cartilage at the base of the tongue.
Covers the windpipe during swallowing.
Prevents food from entering the lungs.
The voice box.
Located in the neck.
Houses the vocal cords.
The throat.
Passageway for both food and air.
Connects the mouth and nasal cavity to the esophagus and larynx.
The heart's natural pacemaker.
Generates electrical impulses that cause the heart to beat.
Abbreviated as SA node.
Carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs.
The only artery to carry deoxygenated blood.
Branches from the right ventricle.
Carries oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart.
The only vein to carry oxygenated blood.
Empties into the left atrium.
Supplies blood to the heart muscle itself.
Blockage can lead to a heart attack.
Its name means 'crown'.
A heart valve between the left atrium and left ventricle.
Also known as the bicuspid valve.
Prevents blood from flowing backward.
A heart valve between the right atrium and right ventricle.
It has three cusps or leaflets.
Prevents blood from flowing backward.
A sac that encloses the heart.
Protects and lubricates the heart.
It has a fibrous and a serous layer.
A heart valve between the left ventricle and the aorta.
Prevents backflow into the ventricle.
It is a semilunar valve.
An organ located in the upper left abdomen.
Filters blood and is a part of the immune system.
It is often called the 'graveyard of red blood cells'.
A muscular organ in the mouth.
Used for tasting, chewing, and swallowing.
Essential for speech.
A ring of muscle at the end of the esophagus.
Prevents stomach acid from flowing back up.
Its malfunction can cause acid reflux.
Commonly known as body fat.
Stores energy and insulates the body.
Its cells are called adipocytes.
Covers the body and lines all body cavities.
Forms glands.
Includes skin and the lining of the digestive tract.
Support cells of the nervous system.
Also known as glial cells.
They do not transmit nerve impulses.
The most common type of bone cell.
They are mature bone cells.
Maintain the bone tissue.
The cells found in cartilage.
They produce and maintain the cartilaginous matrix.
Found in the joints, nose, and ears.
Large white blood cells.
They engulf and digest foreign particles and pathogens.
Means 'big eater' in Greek.
Small, bean-shaped structures of the immune system.
Filter substances that travel through lymphatic fluid.
Can swell when fighting an infection.
A small organ in the chest.
Site of T-cell maturation.
Shrinks after puberty.
Inflammation of a small, finger-like pouch attached to the large intestine.
Causes severe pain in the lower right abdomen.
Often requires surgical removal of the appendix.
Inflammation of the pancreas.
Can be acute or chronic.
Causes severe abdominal pain.
The microscopic filtering units of the kidney.
Responsible for forming urine.
Each kidney contains millions of them.
A cluster of capillaries at the beginning of a nephron.
Filters blood to form urine.
Looks like a tiny ball of yarn.
The smaller air passages in the lungs.
They branch from the bronchi.
Lead to the alveoli.
A double-layered membrane that surrounds the lungs.
Reduces friction during breathing.
Has a parietal and a visceral layer.
A collapsed lung.
Occurs when air gets between the chest wall and lung.
Can be caused by a chest injury.
The central shaft of a long bone.
Also known as the main body of the bone.
Contains the medullary cavity.
A membrane that covers the outer surface of bones.
Contains blood vessels and nerves.
Helps in bone repair and growth.
The dense outer layer of a bone.
Also known as cortical bone.
Provides strength and support.
The spongy, porous bone tissue.
Found at the ends of long bones.
Also known as trabecular bone.
Cells that are responsible for bone formation.
They secrete the matrix that forms bone.
Immature bone cells.
Large, multinucleated cells.
Responsible for bone resorption, or breakdown.
Important for bone remodeling.
A viscous fluid found in the cavities of movable joints.
Lubricates the joints.
Reduces friction between cartilage.
A small, fluid-filled sac.
Located between bones, tendons, and muscles.
Reduces friction during movement.
Three layers of protective membranes.
Surround the brain and spinal cord.
Dura mater, arachnoid mater, and pia mater.
A clear fluid that cushions the brain and spinal cord.
Circulates in the subarachnoid space.
Abbreviated as CSF.
A brain structure responsible for the sense of smell.
Located at the front of the brain.
Receives signals from the nose.
A cranial nerve responsible for sight.
Transmits visual information from the retina to the brain.
Can be damaged by glaucoma.
The longest cranial nerve.
It plays a major role in the parasympathetic nervous system.
Regulates heart rate, digestion, and other involuntary functions.
A cluster of nerve cell bodies.
Located outside the central nervous system.
Often a relay station for nerve signals.
A network of interlacing nerves or blood vessels.
The solar one is a well-known example.
Can be found in the neck, armpit, and lower back.
The pressure in the arteries when the heart beats.
The top number in a blood pressure reading.
Represents the maximum pressure exerted.
The pressure in the arteries when the heart rests between beats.
The bottom number in a blood pressure reading.
Represents the minimum pressure exerted.
A large muscle on the back of the lower leg.
Also known as the calf muscle.
Helps with walking and running.
A large muscle group on the front of the thigh.
Composed of four muscles.
Helps extend the knee.
A large muscle on the back of the upper arm.
It has three heads.
Helps extend the elbow.
A large triangular muscle of the shoulder.
Responsible for arm abduction.
It gives the shoulder its rounded shape.
The large muscle in the chest.
It flexes, adducts, and medially rotates the arm.
Commonly known as 'pecs'.
A large, flat muscle on the back.
It's a major muscle of the back and shoulder.
Helps with pulling movements.
The largest of the three gluteal muscles.
Located in the buttocks.
A primary muscle for hip extension.
A large, triangular muscle of the upper back and neck.
Helps move the head and shoulder blades.
Often gets tense from stress.
The longest muscle in the human body.
Runs across the thigh.
Helps to flex, abduct, and laterally rotate the hip.
A facial muscle that aids in chewing.
The strongest muscle in the body by weight.
Located on the side of the jaw.
A dome-shaped muscle below the lungs.
The primary muscle used in breathing.
Its contraction flattens it, increasing chest volume.
Muscles located between the ribs.
Play a role in breathing.
They help to expand and shrink the chest cavity.
One of the three small bones in the middle ear.
Also known as the stirrup.
The smallest bone in the human body.
One of the three small bones in the middle ear.
Also known as the hammer.
Connected to the eardrum.
One of the three small bones in the middle ear.
Also known as the anvil.
Connects the malleus and the stapes.
A tube that connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx.
Helps to equalize pressure in the middle ear.
Its opening and closing can be felt when yawning or swallowing.
The visible part of the outer ear.
Made of cartilage and skin.
Also known as the auricle.
A specialized extracellular matrix.
Surrounds the plasma membrane of an ovum.
It is a protective layer in the female reproductive cell.
A thick, transparent membrane surrounding the ovum.
Plays a crucial role in fertilization.
Found between the plasma membrane and the corona radiata.
A structure in the ovary.
Contains a single immature egg.
Produces hormones.
A temporary endocrine structure in the ovary.
Develops after an egg is released.
Produces progesterone to prepare the uterus for pregnancy.
A tightly coiled tube located on the back of each testis.
Sperm mature and are stored here.
Connects the testes to the vas deferens.
A muscular tube that carries sperm from the epididymis.
Part of the male reproductive system.
Cut during a vasectomy.
Glands that secrete a fluid that makes up a large part of semen.
Located behind the bladder in males.
The fluid is rich in fructose to provide energy for sperm.
The inner part of the adrenal gland.
Produces stress hormones like adrenaline.
Part of the sympathetic nervous system.
The outer part of the adrenal gland.
Produces steroid hormones like cortisol.
Part of the endocrine system.
A steroid hormone produced by the adrenal glands.
Known as the 'stress hormone'.
Increases blood sugar and helps with metabolism.
A hormone produced by the adrenal cortex.
Regulates blood pressure.
Helps control the balance of salt and water.
A hormone and neurotransmitter.
Commonly known as adrenaline.
Prepares the body for 'fight or flight'.
A female hormone.
Produced primarily by the corpus luteum.
Plays a key role in the menstrual cycle and pregnancy.
A group of female hormones.
Responsible for the development of female secondary sexual characteristics.
Produced by the ovaries.
The primary male sex hormone.
Produced by the testes.
Responsible for the development of male secondary sexual characteristics.
Four small glands located in the neck.
Regulate calcium levels in the blood.
Adjacent to the thyroid gland.
The main hormone produced by the thyroid gland.
Regulates metabolism.
Abbreviated as T4.
A hormone produced by the thyroid gland.
Lowers blood calcium levels.
Opposes the action of parathyroid hormone.
A hormone produced by the pancreas.
Regulates blood sugar levels.
Its deficiency causes diabetes mellitus.
A hormone produced by the pancreas.
Increases blood sugar levels.
Opposes the action of insulin.
A hormone produced by the pancreas and other areas.
Inhibits the release of insulin and glucagon.
Also known as growth hormone inhibiting hormone.
A hormone produced in the stomach.
Stimulates the release of gastric acid.
Helps with digestion.
A hormone produced in the small intestine.
Regulates water balance and pH.
Stimulates the pancreas to release bicarbonate.
A hormone produced by the duodenum.
Stands for Cholecystokinin.
Stimulates the gallbladder to release bile.
The main cell type of the liver.
Makes up about 80% of the liver's mass.
Involved in protein synthesis and detoxification.
A small blood vessel found in the liver.
A type of capillary.
Site of nutrient and waste exchange in the liver.
A specialized macrophage located in the liver.
Removes bacteria and other debris from blood.
Found in the liver's sinusoids.
A large artery that supplies oxygenated blood to the spleen.
Branches from the celiac artery.
Also supplies blood to the pancreas and stomach.
A large artery of the upper limb.
Located in the armpit.
Continuation of the subclavian artery.
Main arteries that supply blood to the head and neck.
There are two of them, one on each side of the neck.
You can feel your pulse here.
A large artery in the thigh.
The main blood supply to the lower limb.
Can be used to check for a pulse in the groin area.
Veins that bring deoxygenated blood from the head back to the heart.
Located in the neck.
There are internal and external ones.
The largest nerve in the body.
Runs from the lower back down the back of the leg.
Pain along this nerve is called sciatica.
The longest cranial nerve.
It plays a major role in the parasympathetic nervous system.
Regulates heart rate, digestion, and other involuntary functions.
The final segment of the vertebral column.
Also known as the tailbone.
Composed of fused vertebrae.
A large, triangular bone at the base of the spine.
It is located between the hip bones.
It is formed by five fused vertebrae.
One of the bones that form the hip bone.
Forms the anterior part of the pelvis.
It is located at the front of the pelvic girdle.
One of the bones that form the hip bone.
Forms the lower and back part of the pelvis.
It's the bone you sit on.
The uppermost and largest bone of the hip.
It forms the prominent part of the hip.
It is a bone, not a part of the intestine.
The bony cavity in the skull.
Houses and protects the eyeball.
Commonly known as the eye socket.
A small bone in the middle ear.
Also known as the hammer.
Connects to the eardrum and incus.
The process of bone formation.
The hardening of cartilage into bone.
Begins in the womb.
The soft spots on a baby's skull.
Spaces between the cranial bones.
Allow for brain growth.
A tough, flexible tissue.
Found at the ends of bones and in the nose and ears.
Acts as a cushion in joints.
A type of joint that is highly movable.
Contains a fluid-filled cavity.
Examples include the knee and shoulder joints.
A joint with a spherical head and a cup-like cavity.
Allows for a wide range of motion.
Examples include the hip and shoulder.
A joint that allows movement in only one plane.
Like a door hinge.
Examples include the elbow and knee.
The first cervical vertebra.
Supports the weight of the skull.
Named after a Greek mythological figure.
The second cervical vertebra.
Allows for the rotation of the head.
It has a dens, or tooth-like process.
The twelve vertebrae in the middle of the spine.
They are located in the chest region.
Each one is articulated with a pair of ribs.
The five vertebrae in the lower back.
They are the largest vertebrae.
Support most of the body's weight.
The seven vertebrae in the neck.
The smallest vertebrae.
Support the head.
Cartilaginous pads between vertebrae.
Act as shock absorbers.
A herniated one can cause pain.
Covers the body and lines all body cavities.
Forms glands.
Includes skin and the lining of the digestive tract.
Provides support, binds tissues together, and protects organs.
Includes bone, cartilage, blood, and fat.
The most abundant tissue in the body.
Tissue composed of cells that can contract.
Responsible for movement.
Includes skeletal, cardiac, and smooth types.
Main tissue of the central and peripheral nervous systems.
Composed of neurons and neuroglia.
Transmits and processes information.
The basic structural and functional unit of life.
The smallest unit of an organism.
The building blocks of the human body.
A membrane-bound organelle in eukaryotic cells.
Contains the cell's genetic material.
Controls the cell's growth and reproduction.
Organelles that generate most of the cell's energy.
Known as the 'powerhouse of the cell'.
Performs cellular respiration.
Cellular structures that are the sites of protein synthesis.
Can be found in the cytoplasm or attached to the endoplasmic reticulum.
Composed of RNA and proteins.
A network of membranes inside a cell.
Involved in protein and lipid synthesis.
Can be rough or smooth.
An organelle that modifies, sorts, and packages proteins.
Also known as the Golgi complex or body.
Prepares proteins for secretion or delivery to other organelles.
Organelles that contain digestive enzymes.
Breaks down waste materials and cellular debris.
Often called the 'garbage disposal' of the cell.
Small organelles that contain enzymes.
Breaks down fatty acids and amino acids.
Produce hydrogen peroxide as a byproduct.
Microscopic cellular membrane protrusions.
Increase the surface area for absorption.
Found on the surface of intestinal and kidney cells.
A directional term in anatomy.
Towards the front of the body.
The opposite of posterior.
A directional term in anatomy.
Towards the back of the body.
The opposite of anterior.
A directional term in anatomy.
Towards the head or upper part of the body.
The opposite of inferior.
A directional term in anatomy.
Towards the feet or lower part of the body.
The opposite of superior.
A directional term in anatomy.
Towards the midline of the body.
The opposite of lateral.
A directional term in anatomy.
Away from the midline of the body.
The opposite of medial.
A directional term in anatomy.
Closer to the trunk or point of attachment.
The opposite of distal.
A directional term in anatomy.
Farther from the trunk or point of attachment.
The opposite of proximal.
A directional term in anatomy.
Closer to the surface of the body.
The opposite of deep.
A directional term in anatomy.
Farther from the surface of the body.
The opposite of superficial.
An anatomical term referring to the palm of the hand.
The front side of the hand.
Relating to the palm.
An anatomical term referring to the sole of the foot.
The bottom surface of the foot.
Relating to the sole.
An anatomical term for the back of an organism.
Also refers to the top of the foot or back of the hand.
The opposite of ventral.
An anatomical term for the front or belly side.
The same as anterior in humans.
The opposite of dorsal.
A vertical plane that divides the body into left and right parts.
A cut along this plane would separate the two halves.
A midsagittal plane divides the body into equal halves.
A horizontal plane that divides the body into superior and inferior parts.
Also known as the axial or horizontal plane.
A cut along this plane would separate the upper and lower body.
A vertical plane that divides the body into anterior and posterior parts.
Also known as the frontal plane.
A cut along this plane would separate the front and back of the body.
A space within the skull.
Contains the brain.
Part of the dorsal body cavity.
A space within the vertebral column.
Contains the spinal cord.
Part of the dorsal body cavity.
The chest cavity.
Contains the heart and lungs.
Part of the ventral body cavity.
The body cavity in the abdomen.
Contains the stomach, liver, and intestines.
Part of the ventral body cavity.
The body cavity in the pelvis.
Contains the bladder and reproductive organs.
The most inferior part of the ventral body cavity.
The navel or belly button.
A common reference point in anatomy.
Remains from where the umbilical cord attached.
An anatomical term referring to the groin area.
The area where the thigh meets the trunk.
Also known as the groin.
An anatomical term for the armpit.
The space below the shoulder joint.
Contains lymph nodes and blood vessels.
An anatomical term referring to the arm.
The upper arm.
The artery here is used to measure blood pressure.
The front of the elbow.
Where blood is often drawn from a vein.
A common anatomical landmark.
An anatomical term for the back of the knee.
Contains a major artery and vein.
The opposite of the patellar region.
An anatomical term referring to the buttocks.
Site for intramuscular injections.
The gluteus maximus is located here.
An anatomical term for the calf.
Refers to the back of the lower leg.
The gastrocnemius muscle is located here.
An anatomical term for the shoulder.
The highest point of the shoulder blade.
The acromion process is part of this.
An anatomical region of the shoulder.
The area of the deltoid muscle.
A common site for vaccinations.
Relating to the eye.
Refers to the vision system.
The ocular lens is a part of the eye.
Relating to the ear.
Refers to the auditory system.
The otic vesicle is an embryonic structure.
Relating to the nose.
Refers to the sense of smell.
The nasal cavity is where air enters the respiratory system.
Relating to the chin.
The chin is also known as the mentum.
The mental foramen is a small hole in the mandible.
Relating to the mouth.
The oral cavity contains the tongue and teeth.
The oral mucosa is the lining of the mouth.
Relating to the neck.
Refers to the vertebrae in the neck.
Also refers to the lower, narrow part of the uterus.
Connects the cerebrum to the spinal cord.
Made up of the midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata.
Controls basic functions like breathing and heart rate.
The two large halves of the cerebrum.
Connected by the corpus callosum.
Responsible for complex brain functions.
A large bundle of nerve fibers.
Connects the two cerebral hemispheres.
Allows communication between the two halves of the brain.
A large opening in the base of the skull.
The spinal cord passes through this.
Allows the skull to connect to the spine.
The immovable joints between the bones of the skull.
They are fibrous joints.
They fuse together over time.
The soft spots on a baby's skull.
Spaces between the cranial bones.
Allow for brain growth and birth.
The three small bones of the middle ear.
Includes the malleus, incus, and stapes.
They transmit sound vibrations to the inner ear.
A hormone and neurotransmitter.
Also known as epinephrine.
Released in response to stress or fear.
A hormone and neurotransmitter.
Also known as norepinephrine.
Works with adrenaline to produce the fight-or-flight response.
A neurotransmitter.
Plays a role in muscle contraction.
Involved in memory and learning.
A neurotransmitter.
Plays a major role in motivation and reward.
Lack of it is associated with Parkinson's disease.
A neurotransmitter.
Contributes to feelings of well-being and happiness.
Antidepressant drugs often target this.
The main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system.
Reduces neuronal excitability.
Its name is an abbreviation.
The main excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system.
Plays a role in learning and memory.
The most abundant neurotransmitter.
A system of glands that produce hormones.
Regulates metabolism, growth, and reproduction.
Includes the thyroid, pituitary, and adrenal glands.
A system of glands that secrete substances onto a surface.
Includes sweat glands and salivary glands.
Its secretions are not hormones.
The system that covers the body.
Includes skin, hair, and nails.
The largest organ system of the body.
A system of vessels and organs.
Part of the circulatory and immune systems.
Includes the spleen, thymus, and lymph nodes.
The system that produces, stores, and eliminates urine.
Also known as the urinary system.
Includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra.
The system responsible for producing offspring.
Includes ovaries and testes.
Produces sex hormones.
The system responsible for gas exchange.
Includes the nose, trachea, and lungs.
Takes in oxygen and expels carbon dioxide.
The system that breaks down food and absorbs nutrients.
Includes the stomach, intestines, and liver.
Also known as the gastrointestinal tract.
The system that transports blood throughout the body.
Includes the heart, blood, and blood vessels.
Also known as the cardiovascular system.
The system of bones and cartilage.
Provides structure, protection, and support.
Includes the skull, spine, and ribs.
The system of muscles.
Enables movement, maintains posture, and produces heat.
Includes skeletal, smooth, and cardiac muscles.
The system that controls and coordinates all body activities.
Includes the brain, spinal cord, and nerves.
Divided into central and peripheral systems.
The study of the structure of the human body.
Often studied with physiology.
A branch of biology.
The study of how the human body works.
Often studied with anatomy.
A branch of biology.
The study of tissues.
A branch of anatomy.
It requires a microscope to view the subject.
The study of cells.
A branch of biology.
Involves looking at cells under a microscope.
The study of disease.
A branch of medical science.
Examines the causes and effects of disease.
